column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: This short play needs rather a long introduction.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: It has had the bad fortune to become a literary problem, and almost all its few readers are so much occupied with the question whether it can be the work of Euripides--and if not his, whose?

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: that they seldom allow themselves to take it on its merits as a stirring and adventurous piece, not particularly profound or subtle, but always full of movement and life and possessing at least one or two scenes of great and penetrating beauty.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: The outlines of the _Rhesus_ Question are these.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: The _Rhesus_ appears in the MSS.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: of Euripides; we know from the Athenian Didascaliae, or Records of Performances, that Euripides wrote a play of the name; some passages in it are quoted by early Alexandrian writers as from "the _Rhesus_ of Euripides;" no passage is quoted under any other name.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: This seems about as strong as external evidence need be.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Yet the ancient introduction to the play mentions that "some think the play spurious," and expresses the odd opinion that "it suggests rather the Sophoclean style.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Further, it tells us that, besides the present opening scene, there were extant two different prologues, one of which was "quite prosy and perhaps concocted by the actors.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: This seems to show that the Alexandrian scholars who tried for the first time to collect the complete works of Euripides, some two centuries after his death, found this play current as "Euripides' _Rhesus_," but that it was credited with three different openings and that its style was felt to be somehow peculiar.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: The peculiarity of style is incontestable.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: It does not to our judgment suggest Sophocles.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: It suggests a young man imitating Aeschylus, and it has a great number of Euripidean expressions.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Hermann, who collected what he took to be "imitations" of early poets in the _Rhesus_, noted only 25 of Sophocles, 38 of Aeschylus, and 84 of Euripides.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Is it, then, the work of a somewhat imitative fourth-century poet, naturally influenced by his great forerunners?

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Hardly: because, with a few exceptions, the verse and diction of the _Rhesus_, are markedly early in character, the verse severe and smooth, the diction direct and rather grandiose, the choral lyrics strictly relevant.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: In Euripides' later years Drama was moving rapidly away from all these things and, as far as we can judge, continued so moving after his death.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: If the _Rhesus_ is a post-classical play it can hardly be honest fourth-century work: it must be deliberately archaistic, a product of the Alexandrian spirit if not actually of the Alexandrian age.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: This is what Hermann believed.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: But unfortunately it is not a bit more like our fragments of Alexandrian tragedy than it is like the _Medea_; and, further, if it is an Alexandrian pseudo-classic tragedy, how did it succeed in deceiving the Alexandrian critics, detectives specially trained for this kind of work?

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Let us try quite a different hypothesis, and begin by accepting the external evidence as true.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: The famous critic, Crates, of the second century B.C., happens to mention--in excuse of what he took to be a slip in the poet's astronomy--that the _Rhesus_ of Euripides was a youthful work.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Now the earliest dated tragedy of Euripides that we possess is the _Alcestis_, B.C. 438, written when he was about forty-six.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: His style may well have been considerably different fifteen or twenty years earlier, and must certainly have been much under the influence of Aeschylus.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: So far, so good.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Then what of the other difficulties, the three different opening scenes and the few passages of late phrasing or technique?

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: One obvious explanation suits both.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: The three different openings pretty clearly imply that the play was reproduced more than once after the poet's death and adapted by the producer for each occasion.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: This happened to many plays of Euripides, and in one case we even know the name of the producer; he was Euripides the Younger, son of the poet.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Among other things we have reason to believe that he wrote some parts of the _Iphigenia in Aulis_.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: And in this connexion we can hardly help noticing that the _Iphigenia in Aulis_, like the _Rhesus_ and like no other Greek tragedy, has two alternative openings, one a dull prologue and one a lyrical scene in anapaests under the stars.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: The general style of the two plays is utterly different; the _Iphigenia_ is most typically late Euripidean; but one would not be surprised to learn that they had both passed at some time through the same revising hand.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: This hypothesis seems to work well.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: But one difficulty remains.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: We have so far gone on the supposition that Euripides at twenty-five or thirty perhaps wrote very differently from Euripides at forty-six, and that the manner we call Euripidean is only the manner of his later life.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: There is nothing improbable in this suggestion, but have we any evidence?

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Yes, a very little, and unfortunately it does not say what we want.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: We have some fragments--twenty lines altogether--preserved from the _Peliades_, with which Euripides won his first victory in the year 455, seventeen years before the _Alcestis_, and as far as they go they are just in his ordinary manner--a good deal more so, in fact, than much of the _Alcestis_ is.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Let us face this difficulty.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: The ordinary style of Euripides is full, flexible, lucid, antithetic, studiously simple in vocabulary and charged with philosophic reflection.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: If we look in his extant remains for any trace of a style, like that of the _Rhesus_, which is comparatively terse, rich, romantic, not shrinking from rare words and strong colour and generally untinged by philosophy, we shall find the nearest approach to it in the _Cyclops_.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Next to the _Cyclops_ I am not sure what play would come, but the _Alcestis_ would not be far off.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: It has especially several Epic forms which cannot be paralleled in tragedy.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Now the conjunction of these two plays with the _Rhesus_ is significant.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: The three seem to be three earliest of the extant plays; they are also--if we count the _Heraclidae_ as mutilated--the three shortest.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: But, what is more important, the _Cyclops_ is not a tragedy but a satyr-play, and the _Alcestis_ is a tragedy of a special sort, written to take the place of a satyr-play.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: It is a tragedy with some half grotesque figures and a fantastic atmosphere.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: This is no place for a close analysis of the diction of the various works of Euripides; but taking one rough test, just for what it is worth, we may try to count the number of words in each play which are not found elsewhere in Euripides.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: The _Medea_, a central sort of play, has in its 1419 lines 103 such words.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: The _Alcestis_, with 1163 lines, has 122; the _Rhesus_, with less than 1000 lines, has 177; the _Cyclops_, with only 701 lines, has actually 220.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: This calculation is doubtless slightly inexact: in any case it is worth very little until it is carefully analysed.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: But on the whole it accords with my general impression that the _Rhesus_ in its variation from the Euripidean norm goes further than the _Alcestis_, and not so far as the _Cyclops_, and goes in very much the same direction.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: I feel in the _Rhesus_ a good deal of that curious atmosphere, not exactly comic, but wild and extravagant, which the Greeks felt to be suited to the Satyr horde; the atmosphere normally breathed by the one-eyed Giant of the cavern on volcanic Aetna, or the drunken and garlanded Heracles who wrestles with Death and cracks his ribs for him at midnight among the tombs.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: The whole scene and setting of the _Rhesus_; the man-wolf crawling away into the darkness and his two enemies presently crawling in out of the same darkness with his bloody spoils; the divine Thracian king with his round targe that shines by night and his horses whiter than the snow; the panic of the watch, the vaunting of the doomed chieftain, the goddess disguised as another goddess, the thrilling half-farcical scene where the spy Odysseus is actually caught and befools his captors: these things are not of course comic, like some incidents in the _Cyclops_.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: They belong to tragedy; but they are near the outside limit of the tragic convention, and would perhaps be most at home in a pro-satyric tragedy like the _Alcestis_.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: In the upshot I see no adequate reason for rejecting the external evidence which makes this play a work of Euripides, if we suppose it to be an early pro-satyric play which was produced again after the poet's death by Euripides the Younger or some contemporary.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Most scholars, however, prefer to think it simply an archaistic work of the fourth century.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: On this theory the Alexandrians when looking for the _Rhesus_ of Euripides found an anonymous play called _Rhesus_ and accepted it for what it was worth.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: The Prologues mentioned in the argument would perhaps belong to other plays of the same name; one, no doubt, to the real play of Euripides.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: The rich and severe style may, for all we know--for direct evidence fails us--be the natural mark of some reactionary archaistic school about the time of Plato or Aristotle.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: The same date might well be indicated by the great interest our play takes in the Iliad, and by its almost "Alexandrian" use of the gods as ornamental machinery.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: I cannot call such a theory improbable; but it really amounts to rejecting the external evidence in order to place the _Rhesus_ in a period of tragic style of which we happen to know nothing.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: It is certainly not confirmed by the scanty fragments we possess of Theodectes or Chairemon.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: And, if one is to venture into more speculative and subjective arguments, I find it rather hard to think of any lyric poet except Euripides who could have written the Adrasteia chorus or the lines about the Nightingale in the Watchers' Song; of any playwright except Euripides who would have ended a play of gallant martial adventure with the vision of a solitary mother clasping her dead son.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: There are many other passages, too, like the mysterious sobbing in the dark that heralds the entry of the wounded Thracian, and the final passing out of the army to its certain defeat, which seem to me more like undeveloped genius than common imitative mediocrity.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: If a nameless fourth-century poet wrote this play, I think we should have heard more of him.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: The story of the play is taken straight from the Doloneia, an Epic rhapsody which now takes its place as the Tenth Book of the Iliad, but was very likely independent in the time of Euripides (_Rise of the Greek Epic_, p. 313 f.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: The play seems in one or two points to follow a more archaic model than the version in our Homer.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: In Rhesus himself--the name is said to be the Thracian form of _rex_[1]--we seem to have the traditional divine king of the Thracian tribes about Pangaion, seen through the eyes of Greek romance.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: He is the son of the greatest of Rivers and the Muse of the Mountain: she is simply "The Muse," otherwise nameless, and we are lost if we try to bind her down to the identity of any Greek goddess.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Like many Thracian heroes Rhesus has a dash of the Sun-god in him, the burning targe, the white horses and the splendour.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Like them he is a boaster and a deep drinker, a child of battle and of song.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Like other divine kings he dies in his youth and strength, and keeps watch over his people from some "feasting presence, full of light," where he lies among the buried silver-veins of Pangaion.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: If the uttermost need comes, doubtless he will wake again.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: When the Athenians began making their dangerous settlements on the coast of Thrace--ten thousand settlers were massacred by Rhesus's people about 465 B.C.: Amphipolis not fully established till 437--they found the legend of Rhesus in the air, and eventually they thought it prudent to send for his hallowed bones from the Troad, where they were supposed to be buried, and give them a tomb in the Athenian colony.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Possibly that pacified him.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: And his legend in the mouth of the poets seemed perhaps like the story of his own mountaineers, multitudes of strong men, stormy and chivalrous, terrible in onset, who somehow in the end melted away before the skill and persistent courage of a civilised Greek city.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: The date and authorship of the play are unknown; it probably belongs to the Fifth Century B.C., and is attributed to Euripides.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: RHESUS

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: It is a cloudy but moonlight night on the plain before Troy.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: vv.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: The Trojans and their allies have won a decisive victory and are camping on the open field close to the Greek outposts.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: The scene is in front of a rude tent or hut that has been set up for_ HECTOR, _the Trojan leader.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: A watch-fire burns low in front.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Far off at the back can be seen rows of watch-fires in the Greek camp.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: The road to Troy is in front to the left; the road to Mount Ida leads far away to the right.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: All is silence; then a noise outside.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Enter tumultuously a band of Trojan Pickets.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: VARIOUS VOICES.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: The dash -- in these passages indicates a new speaker.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: On to the Princes quarters!

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Ho!

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Who is awake?

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: What man-at-arms, Or squire or groom?

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Let Hector know New rumour of alarms From sentinels who stand at mark The four long watches of the dark, While others sleep.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Uplift thine head, O Hector!

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: On thine elbow rise, Unhood the eagle of thine eyes, Up from thy leaf-strewn bed!

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Lord Hector!

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: HECTOR (_coming out from the tent_).

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: vv.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Who goes there?

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Who cries?

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: A friend?

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: The watchword!

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: By what right Do men come prowling in the night Across my quarters?

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Come!

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Speak out.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: LEADER.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: A picket, Lord.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: HECTOR.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: In such a rout?

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: LEADER.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Be not afraid, Lord.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: HECTOR.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: I am not.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Is there an ambush?

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: No?

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Then what, In Gods name, brings you from your post With no clear tale to speak, To spread this turmoil through a host That lies in harness--do ye all Know nothing?

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: out against the wall And gateways of the Greek?

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: CHORUS (_various voices confusedly_).

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Strophe.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: To arms!

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: To arms, Lord Hector!

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Send First where the allied armies lie, Bid them draw sword and make an end Of sleep.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Let someone fly And get the horses armour on!

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Who goes with me to Panthoös son?

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Whos for Sarpêdon and the Lycians?

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: None [vv.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Hath seen the priest go by?

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Ho, Captain of the Runners, ho!

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Ho, Trojans of the hornèd bow!

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: String, string!

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: For need is nigh.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: HECTOR.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Ha, silence there!

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: First words of fear, Then comfort.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: All an empty swell!

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: It seems the lash of trembling Pan Hath caught you.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Speak, if speak ye can.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: What tidings?

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Not a word is clear Of the whole tale ye tell.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: The turmoil subsides, the_ LEADER _comes forward_.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: LEADER.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Antistr.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Great beacons in the Argive line Have burned, my chief, through half the night.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: The shipyard timbers seemed to shine.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Then, clear against the light, Toward Agamemnons tent the whole Army in tumult seemed to roll, As stirred by some strange voice, shoal after shoal.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: A night of such discord Was never seen.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: And we, in dread What such things boded, turned and sped Hither; dost blame us, Lord?

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: HECTOR (_after a moment of thought_).

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: No!

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Welcome, friend, with all thy tale of fear!

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: It shows they mean to fly: they mean to clear Decks in the dark and so delude my sight .

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: vv.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: I like that beacon-burning in the night.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: O Zeus above, who checked my conquering way, Who baulked the hungry lion of his prey Or ever I could sweep my country clear Of these despoilers, dost thou hate my spear?

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Had but the suns bright arrows failed me not, I neer had rested till the ships were hot With fire, and through the tents upon the plain This bloody hand had passed and passed again!

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Myself, I longed to try the battle-cast By night, and use Gods vantage to the last, But sage and prophet, learned in the way Of seercraft, bade me wait for dawn of day, And then--leave no Greek living in the land.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: They wait not, they, for what my prophets planned So sagely.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: In the dark a runaway Beats a pursuer.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Through our whole array Send runners!

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Bid them shake off sleep and wait Ready with shield and spear.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Tis not too late To catch them as they climb on board, and slash Their crouching shoulders till the gangways splash With blood, or teach them, fettered leg and arm, To dig the stiff clods of some Trojan farm.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: LEADER.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: My Prince, thy words run fast.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Nor thou nor I Have knowledge yet that the Greeks mean to fly.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: HECTOR.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: What makes them light their beacons?

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Tell me, what?

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: LEADER.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: vv.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: God knows!

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: And, for my part, I like it not.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: HECTOR.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: What, feared?

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Thou wouldst be feared of everything!

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: LEADER.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: They never lit such light before, O King.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: HECTOR.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: They never fled, man, in such wild dismay.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: LEADER (_yielding_).

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Twas all thy work.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Judge thou, and we obey.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: HECTOR.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: My word is simple.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Arm and face the foe.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: A sound of marching without.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: LEADER.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Who comes?

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Aeneas, and in haste, as though Fraught with some sudden tiding of the night.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Enter_ AENEAS.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: AENEAS.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Hector, what means it?

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Watchers in affright Who gather shouting at thy doors, and then Hold midnight council, shaking all our men?

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: HECTOR.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: To arms, Aeneas!

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Arm from head to heel!

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: AENEAS.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: vv.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: What is it?

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Tidings?

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Doth the Argive steal Some march, some ambush in the days eclipse?

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: HECTOR.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Tis flight, man!

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: They are marching to the ships.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: AENEAS.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: How knowst thou?

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Have we proof that it is flight?

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: HECTOR.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: They are burning beacon-fires the livelong night.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: They never mean to wait till dawn.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Behind That screen of light they are climbing in the blind Dark to their ships--unmooring from our coast.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: AENEAS (_looking toward the distant fires: after a pause_).

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: God guide them!

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Why then do you arm the host?

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: HECTOR.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: I mean to lame them in their climbing, I And my good spear, and break them as they fly.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Black shame it were, and folly worse than shame, To let these spoilers go the road they came Unpunished, when God gives them to us here.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: AENEAS.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Brother, I would thy wit were like thy spear!

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: But Nature wills not one man should be wise In all things; each must seek his separate prize.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: And thine is battle pure.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: There comes this word Of beacons, on the touch thy soul is stirred: [vv.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: They fly!

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Out horse and chariots!

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Out withal Past stake and trench, while night hangs like a pall!

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Say, when we cross that coiling depth of dyke, We find the foe not fled, but turned to strike; One check there, and all hope of good return Is gone.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: How can our men, returning, learn The tricks of the palisade?

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: The chariots how Keep to the bridges on the trenches brow, Save with jammed wheels and broken axles?

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Aye, And say thou conquer: other wars yet lie Before thee.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Peleus son, for all his ire, Will never let thee touch the ships with fire Or pounce on his Greek lambs.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: The man will bide No wrong and standeth on a tower of pride.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Nay, brother, let the army, head on shield, Sleep off its long days labour in the field: Then, send a spy; find someone who will dare Creep to yon Argive camp.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Then, if tis clear They mean flight, on and smite them as they fly.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Else, if the beacons hide some strategy, The spy will read it out, and we can call A council.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Thus speak I, my general.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: CHORUS.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Strophe.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Tis good!

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Tis wisdom!

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Prince, give heed And change the word thy passion gave.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: No soldier loveth, in his need, The glory of a chief too brave.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: A spy is best: a spy, to learn For what strange work those beacons burn All night beside the guarded wave.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: HECTOR.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: vv.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Ye all so wish it?

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Well, ye conquer me.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: To_ AENEAS) Go thou and calm the allies.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: There will be Some stir among them, hearing of these high And midnight councils.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: I will seek the spy To send to the Greek camp.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: If there we learn Of some plot hatching, on the mans return I straight will call thee and share counsels.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: So.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: But wait attentive.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: If he says they go Shipward and plan to escape, one trumpet call Shall warn thee, and I wait no more, but fall On camp and hulls, or ever dawn can rise.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: AENEAS.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Aye, haste and send him.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Now thy plans are wise, And when need comes I am with thee, sword by sword.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Exit_ AENEAS.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: HECTOR (_turning to the Guards and other soldiers_).

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Ye gathered Trojans, sharers of my word, Who dares to creep through the Greek lines alone?

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Who will so help his fatherland?

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Doth none Offer?

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Must I do everything, one hand Alone, to save our allies and our land?

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: A lean dark man pushes forward from the back.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: DOLON.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: I, Prince!

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: I offer for our Citys sake To go disguised to the Greek ships, to make Their counsels mine, and here bring word to thee.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: If that be thy full service, I agree.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: HECTOR.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: vv.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Dolon the Wolf!

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: A wise wolf and a true!

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Thy fathers house was praised when first I knew Troy: this shall raise it twofold in our eyes.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: DOLON.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Tis wise to do good work, but also wise To pay the worker.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Aye, and fair reward Makes twofold pleasure, though the work be hard.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: HECTOR.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: So be it: an honest rule.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Do thou lay down What guerdon likes thee best--short of my crown.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: DOLON.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: I care not for thy crowned and care-fraught life.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: HECTOR.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Wouldst have a daughter of the King to wife?

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: DOLON.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: I seek no mate that might look down on me.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: HECTOR.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Good gold is ready, if that tempteth thee.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: DOLON.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: We live at ease and have no care for gold.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: HECTOR.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Well, Troy hath other treasures manifold.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: DOLON.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: vv.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Pay me not now, but when the Greeks are taen.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: HECTOR.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: The Greeks!

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Choose any save the Atridae twain.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: DOLON.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Kill both, an it please thee.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: I make prayer for none.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: HECTOR.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Thou wilt not ask for Ajax, Îleus son?

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: DOLON.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: A princely hand is skilless at the plough.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: HECTOR.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Tis ransom, then?

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: What prisoner cravest thou?

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: DOLON.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: I said before, of gold we have our fill.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: HECTOR.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: For spoils and armour .

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: thou shalt choose at will.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: DOLON.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Nail them for trophies on some temple wall.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: HECTOR.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: What seeks the man?

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: What prize more rich than all?

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: DOLON.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Achilles horses!

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Murmurs of surprise.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Yes, I need a great Prize.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: I am dicing for my life with Fate.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: HECTOR.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: vv.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Fore God, I am thy rival, if thy love Lies there.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Undying was the breed thereof, And these shall never die, who bear to war Great Peleus son, swift gleaming like a star.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Poseidon, rider of the wild sea-drift, Tamed them, men say, and gave them for his gift To Peleus.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: None the less, since I have stirred Hopes, I will baulk them not.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: I pledge my word, Achilles steeds, a rare prize, shall be thine.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: DOLON.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: I thank thee.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Tis indeed a prize more fine Than all in Troy.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Grudge me not that; there be Guerdons abundant for a Prince like thee.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Exit_ HECTOR.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: CHORUS.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Antistr.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: O peril strange, O fearful prize!

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Yet win it and thy life hath wings: A deed of glory in mens eyes, And greatness, to be wooed of kings.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: If God but hearken to the right, Thou drinkest to the full this night The cup of mans imaginings.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: DOLON.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: He stands waiting a moment looking out into the dark.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: There lies the way.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: But first I must go find At home some body-shelter to my mind; Then, forward to the ships of Argolis!

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: LEADER.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: vv.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: What other raiment wilt thou need than this?

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: DOLON.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: A garb for work, for night; a thieving guise.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: LEADER.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Tis good to learn the wisdoms of the wise.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: What will thy wrapping be?

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: DOLON.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: A grey wolfs hide Shall wrap my body close on either side; My head shall be the mask of gleaming teeth, My arms fit in the forepaws, like a sheath, My thighs in the hinder parts.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: No Greek shall tell Tis not a wolf that walks, half visible, On four feet by the trenches and around The ship-screen.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: When it comes to empty ground It stands on two.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: That is the plan, my friend!

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: LEADER.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Now Maian Hermes guide thee to thy end And home safe!

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Well he loves all counterfeit .

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Good work is there; may good luck go with it!

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: DOLON (_to himself gazing out toward the Greek camp_).

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: There, and then back!

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: And on this belt shall bleed Odysseus head--or why not Diomede?

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: To prove my truth.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Ere dawn can touch the land I shall be here, and blood upon my hand.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Exit_ DOLON.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: CHORUS.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: vv.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Thymbraean, Delian, Birth divine, That walkest Lycias inmost shrine, Come, strong to guard, to guide, to follow, Come, bow in hand and girt with night, To help thy Dardans as of old, When stone by stone thy music rolled-- O conquering Strength, O Sire Apollo!

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Young Ilion into towers of light.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Grant that he reach the shipyard, creep Keen-eyed through all that host asleep, Then back to home and hearth, yet living, Where now his father prays alone: Yea, grant that, when the Greeks are slain, Our wolf shall mount with scourge and rein Those coursers of the sea-gods giving, Whom Peleus drove in days foregone.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Alone in those Greek ships to stake His life, for home and countrys sake: Tis wondrous!

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Few be hearts so true When seas across the bulwark break, And sunlight sickens oer the crew.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Ah, Phrygia still hath hearts of rock!

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: The Phrygian spear flies fast and far!

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Where shall ye find the fool to mock Our works in war?

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Whom will he stab a-sleeping, whom, The quick grey wolf, the crawling doom?

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Grant that he slay the Spartan!

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Nay, Or Agamemnons head and plume [vv.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: To Helen bear at dawn of day!

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: A lightsome dawn to hear her wail Her brother sworn, her King who came To Ilion with his thousand sail, And swords, and flame!

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: As the song ends_ DOLON _reappears, in the disguise of a wolf.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: The Guards gather round him, bidding him godspeed as he crawls off in the dark towards the Greek camp.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Meantime from the direction of Mount Ida has entered a_ SHEPHERD _who goes to_ HECTORs _door and calls.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: The Guards seeing him return to their places.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: SHEPHERD.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Ho, Master!

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Enter_ HECTOR _from tent_.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: I would it ofttimes were my luck to share As goodly news with thee as now I bear.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: HECTOR.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: What dulness hangs about these shepherds!

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Block, Comst thou to us with tidings of thy flock Here in the field in arms?

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Who wants thee here?

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Thou knowst my house; thou knowst my fathers.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: There Tell all about thy lucky lambs.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Now go.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: SHEPHERD.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Dull wits, we shepherds!

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Aye, twas alway so.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Yet still, there is some good news to be told.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: HECTOR.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: vv.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: A truce there to thy gossip of the fold!

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Our dealings are of war, of sword and spear.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: He turns to go.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: SHEPHERD.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Aye; so were mine.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: That is what brought me here.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: HECTORs _manner changes_.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: A chief comes yonder, leading a great band Of spears, with help to thee and all the land.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: HECTOR.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: From whence?

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: How do his name and lineage run?

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: SHEPHERD.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: He comes from Thrace, the River Strymons son.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: HECTOR.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Rhesus!

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Not Rhesus, here on Trojan soil?

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: SHEPHERD.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Thou hast guessed.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: That eases me of half my toil.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: HECTOR.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: What makes he there towards Ida?

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: All astray Thus from the plain and the broad waggon-way!

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: SHEPHERD.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: I know not rightly, though one well may guess.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Tis hard to land at night, with such a press Of spears, on a strange coast, where rumours tell Of foes through all the plain-land.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: We that dwell On Ida, in the rock, Troys ancient root And hearth-stone, were well frighted, through the mute [vv.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: And wolfish thickets thus to hear him break.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: A great and rushing noise those Thracians make, Marching.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: We, all astonied, ran to drive Our sheep to the upmost heights.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Twas some Argive, We thought, who came to sweep the mountain clear And waste thy folds; till suddenly our ear Caught at their speech, and knew twas nothing Greek.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Then all our terror fled.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: I ran to seek Some scout or pioneer who led the van And called in Thracian: Ho, what child of man Doth lead you?

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: From what nation do ye bring This host with aid to Ilion and her king?

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: He told me what I sought, and there I stood Watching; and saw one gleaming like a God, Tall in the darkness on a Thracian car.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: A plate of red gold mated, like a bar, His coursers necks, white, white as fallen snow.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: A carven targe, with golden shapes aglow, Hung oer his back.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Before each coursers head A Gorgon, to the frontlet riveted, With bells set round--like stories that they tell Of Pallas shield--made music terrible.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: The numbers of that host no pen could write Nor reckon; tis a multitudinous sight, Long lines of horsemen, lines of targeteers, Archers abundant; and behind them veers A wavering horde, light-armed, in Thracian weed.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: A friend is come to Ilion in her need Gainst whom no Argive, let him fly or stand, Shall aught avail nor scape his conquering hand.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: LEADER.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: vv.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Lo, when the Gods breathe gently oer a town, All runs to good, as water-streams run down.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: HECTOR (_bitterly_).

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Aye, when my spear hath fortune, when God sends His favour, I shall find abundant friends.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: I need them not; who never came of yore To help us, when we rolled to death before The war-swell, and the wind had ripped our sail.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Then Rhesus taught us Trojans what avail His words are.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: He comes early to the feast; Where was he when the hunters met the beast?

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Where, when we sank beneath the Argive spear?

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: LEADER.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Well mayst thou mock and blame thy friend.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Yet here He comes with help for Troy.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Accept him thou.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: HECTOR.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: We are enough, who have held the wall till now.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: LEADER.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Master, dost think already that our foe Is taen?

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: HECTOR.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: I do.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: To-morrows light will show.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: LEADER.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: vv.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Have care.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Fate often flings a backward cast.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: HECTOR.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: I hate the help that comes when need is past .

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Howbeit, once come, I bid him welcome here As guest--not war-friend; guest to share our cheer.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: The thanks are lost, he might have won from us.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: LEADER.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: My general, to reject an ally thus Must needs make hatred.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: SHEPHERD.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: The mere sight of those I saw would sure cast fear upon our foes.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: HECTOR (_yielding reluctantly, with a laugh_).

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Ah, well; thy words are prudent; and (_To_ SHEPHERD) thine eyes See glorious things.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: With all these panoplies Of gold that filled our Shepherds heart with joy, Bid Rhesus welcome, as war-friend to Troy.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Exit_ SHEPHERD; HECTOR _returns to his tent, amid the joy of the soldiers_.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: CHORUS.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Now Adrasteia be near and guard Our lips from sin, lest the end be hard!

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: But he cometh, he cometh, the Child of the River!

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: The pride of my heart it shall roll unbarred.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: We craved thy coming; yea, need was strong [vv.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: In the Hall of thy lovers, O child of Song; Thy mother the Muse and her fair-bridged River They held thee from us so long, so long!

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: By Strymons torrent alone she sang, And Strymon shivered and coiled and sprang; And her arms went wide to the wild sweet water, And the love of the River around her rang.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: We hail thee, Fruit of the Rivers seed, Young Zeus of the Dawn, on thy starry steed!

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: O ancient City, O Idas daughter, Is God the Deliverer found indeed?

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: And men shall tell of thee, Ilion mine, Once more a-harping at days decline, Mid laughing of lovers and lays and dances And challenge on challenge of circling wine?

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: When the Greek is smitten that day shall be, And fled to Argolis over the sea: O mighty of hand, O leader of lances, Smite him, and heaven be good to thee!

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Thou Rider golden and swift and sheer, Achilles falters: appear!

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: appear!

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: The car like flame where the red shield leapeth, The fell white steeds and the burning spear!

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: No Greek shall boast he hath seen thy face And danced again in the dancing place; And the land shall laugh for the sheaves she reapeth, Of spoilers dead by a sword from Thrace.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Enter_ RHESUS _in dazzling white armour, followed by his_ [vv.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: CHARIOTEER _and Attendants.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: The_ CHARIOTEER _carries his golden shield.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: The_ CHORUS _break into a shout of All Hail!

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: LEADER.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: All hail, great King!

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: A whelp indeed Is born in Thracias lion fold, Whose leap shall make strong cities bleed.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Behold his body girt with gold, And hark the pride of bells along The frontlet of that targes hold.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: CHORUS.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: A God, O Troy, a God and more!

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Tis Ares self, this issue strong Of Strymon and the Muse of song, Whose breath is fragrant on thy shore!

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Re-enter_ HECTOR.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: RHESUS.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Lord Hector, Prince of Ilion, noble son Of noble sires, all hail!

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Long years have run Since last we greeted, and tis joy this day To see thy fortunes firm and thine array Camped at the foes gate.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Here am I to tame That foe for thee, and wrap his ships in flame.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: HECTOR.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Thou child of Music and the Thracian flood, Strymonian Rhesus, truth is alway good In Hectors eyes.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: I wear no double heart.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Long, long ago thou shouldst have borne thy part [vv.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: In Ilions labours, not have left us here, For all thy help, to sink beneath the spear.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Why didst thou--not for lack of need made plain!

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Not come, not send, not think of us again?

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: What grave ambassadors prayed not before Thy throne, what herald knelt not at thy door?

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: What pride of gifts did Troy not send to thee?

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: And thou, a lord of Barbary even as we, Thou, brother of our blood, like one at sup Who quaffs his fill and flings away the cup, Hast flung to the Greeks my city!

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Yet, long since, Twas I that found thee but a little prince And made thee mighty, I and this right hand; When round Pangaion and the Paiôns land, Front against front, I burst upon the brood Of Thrace and broke their targes, and subdued Their power to thine.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: The grace whereof, not small, Thou hast spurned, and when thy kinsmen, drowning, call, Comest too late.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Thou!

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Others there have been These long years, not by nature of our kin .

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Some under yon rough barrows thou canst see Lie buried; they were true to Troy and me; And others, yet here in the shielded line Or mid the chariots, parching in the shine Of noonday, starving in the winds that bite Through Ilions winter, still endure and fight On at my side.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Twas not their way, to lie On a soft couch and, while the cups go by, Pledge my good health, like thee, in Thracian wine.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: I speak as a free man.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: With thee and thine Hector is wroth, and tells thee to thy face.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: RHESUS.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: vv.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Thy way is mine, friend.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Straight I run my race In word and deed, and bear no double tongue.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: I tell thee, more than thine my heart was wrung, Yea, angered past all durance, thus to stay Back from thy battles.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Twas a folk that lay Hard on my borders, Scythians of the north; Just when my host for Troy had started forth, They fell upon our homes.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: I had reached the coast Of the Friendless Sea and purposed to have crossed My Thracians there.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: We turned; and all that plain Is trampled in a mire of Scythian slain Ploughed by our spears, and blood of Thrace withal Not stinted.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: This it was that drowned thy call For help and held me back from Ilions need.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: I broke their power; the princes of their breed I took to hostage, made their elders swear To bring my house due tribute, year by year, Then, never lagging, crossed the Pontus mouth, Marched by long stages through Bithynia south And here am come .

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: not drunken with the feast, As thou wouldst have me be, not lulled to rest In golden chambers.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: In this harness hard I have borne my nights of winter storm that starred The Euxine into ice and scared the strong Paionians.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Long I have been, but not too long To save thee yet.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Friend, this is the tenth year Thou labourest on unceasing, with no clear Vantage; day creeps by day, and Ares throws The same red dice for thee and for thy foes.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Now, hear my vow.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Before one days eclipse I swear to break their wall, to burn their ships And slay their princes.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: On the second day [vv.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: I leave this soil and take my homeward way, Thy pains relieved.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: No Trojan of the land Need move, nor turn the buckler in his hand.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Alone my late-comers will turn the tide And smite your Greeks, for all their bitter pride.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: CHORUS.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: The Trojan soldiers, who have been listening with delight, here break out in irrepressible applause.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: All hail!

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Sweet words and faithful heart!

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Only may Zeus avert From those proud lips the Wrath that none may bear!

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Never a galleon bore, Now, nor in days of yore, Prince like to thee, so valiant and so fair.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: How shall Achilles, how Shall Ajax bear him now, Or face thy lance?

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: May I but stand that day Watching to see him reel Broken beneath thy steel, And once in blood his many murders pay!

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: RHESUS.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Yea, more atonement thou shalt take from me For this slow help.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: May Adrasteia see My heart and pardon!

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: When we two have set Troy free from these who compass her with hate, Soon as the Gods have had their first-fruits, I With thee will sail--so help me Zeus on high!

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: And sack all Hellas with the sword, till these Doers of deeds shall know what suffering is.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: HECTOR.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: vv.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: By heaven, could I once see this peril rolled Past us, and live in Ilion as of old, Untrembling, I would thank my gods!

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: To seek Argos and sack the cities of the Greek-- Twere not such light work as thou fanciest.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: RHESUS.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: These Greeks that face thee, are they not their best?

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: HECTOR.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: We seek not better.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: These do all we need.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: RHESUS.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: When these are beaten, then, we have done the deed.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: HECTOR.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Lose not thy path watching a distant view.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: RHESUS.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Thou seemst content to suffer, not to do?

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: HECTOR.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: I have a kingdom large by mine own right.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: What station will best please thee in this fight To ground the targe and stablish thine array?

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Right, left, or midmost in the allies?

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Say.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: RHESUS.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Twould please me best to fight these Greeks alone.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Yet, if twould irk thine honour not to have thrown One firebrand on the ships with me, why, then Set us to face Achilles and his men.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: HECTOR.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: vv.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Achilles?

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Nay, his spear ye cannot meet.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: RHESUS.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: How so?

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Fame said he sailed here with the fleet.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: HECTOR.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: He sailed, and he is here.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: But some despite Gainst the great King now keeps him from the fight.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: RHESUS.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Who next to him hath honour in their host?

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: HECTOR.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Next, to my seeming, Ajax hath the most, Or Diomede.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: But Odysseus is a tough And subtle fox, and brave; aye, brave enough.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: No man of them hath harmed us more than he.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: He climbed here to Athenas sanctuary One night, and stole her image clean away To the Argive ships.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Yes, and another day, Guised as a wandering priest, in rags, he came And walked straight through the Gates, made loud acclaim Of curses on the Greek, spied out alone All that he sought in Ilion, and was gone-- Gone, and the watch and helpers of the Gate Dead!

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: And in every ambush they have set By the old Altar, close to Troy, we know He sits--a murderous reptile of a foe!

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: RHESUS.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: vv.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: No brave man seeks so dastardly to harm His battle-foes; he meets them arm to arm.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: This Greek of thine, this sitter like a thief In ambush, I will make of him my chief Care.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: I will take him living, drive a straight Stake through him, and so star him at the Gate To feed your wide-winged vultures.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Tis the death Most meet for a lewd thief, who pillageth Gods sanctuary, or so we hold in Thrace.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: HECTOR (_making no answer_).

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Seek first some sleep.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: There still remains a space Of darkness.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: I will show the spot that best May suit you, somewhat sundered from the rest.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Should need arise, the password of the night Is Phoebus: see your Thracians have it right.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Turning to the Guards before he goes.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Advance beyond your stations, men, at some Distance, and stay on watch till Dolon come With word of the Argives counsel.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: If his vow Prosper, he should be nearing us by now.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Exeunt_ HECTOR _and_ RHESUS _and Attendants.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: The Guards, who have been below, come forward sleepily from the camp fire, and sit watching by_ HECTORs _tent_.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: CHORUS.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Say, whose is the watch?

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Who exchanges With us?

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: The first planets to rise Are setting; the Pleiades seven [vv.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Move low on the margin of heaven, And the Eagle is risen and ranges The mid-vault of the skies.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: ANOTHER.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: No sleeping yet!

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Up from your couches And watch on, the sluggards ye are!

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: The moon-maidens lamp is yet burning.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: THIRD GUARD.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Oh, the morning is near us, the morning!

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Even now his fore-runner approaches, Yon dim-shining star.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: DIVERS GUARDS (_talking_).

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Who drew the first night-watch?

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: ANOTHER.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Twas one Koroibos, called the Mygdons Son.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: THE GUARD.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: And after?

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: THE OTHER.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: The Mount Taurus men Had second watch: from them again The Mysians took it.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: We came then.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: A GUARD.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Tis surely time.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Who will go tell The fifth watch?

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Tis the Lycians spell By now; twas thus the portions fell.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: ANOTHER.
