column11: vv.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Nay, hearken!

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Again she is crying Where death-laden Simoïs falls, Of the face of dead Itys that stunned her, Of grief grown to music and wonder: Most changeful and old and undying The nightingale calls.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: ANOTHER.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: And on Ida the shepherds are waking Their flocks for the upland.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: I hear The skirl of a pipe very distant.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: ANOTHER.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: And sleep, it falls slow and insistent.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Tis perilous sweet when the breaking Of dawn is so near.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: DIVERS GUARDS (_talking_).

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Why have we still no word nor sign Of that scout in the Argive line?

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: ANOTHER.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: I know not; he is long delayed.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: ANOTHER.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: God send he trip not on the blade Of some Greek in an ambuscade!

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: ANOTHER.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: It may be.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: I am half afraid.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: LEADER.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: vv.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Our time is past!

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Up, men, and tell The fifth watch.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Tis the Lycians spell Now, as the portions fairly fell.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: The Guards pass out to waken the Lycians.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: The stage is empty and dark except for the firelight, when a whisper is heard at the back.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Presently enter_ ODYSSEUS _and_ DIOMEDE _in dull leather armour_, DIOMEDE _carrying at his belt_ DOLONs _wolf-skin and mask_.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: ODYSSEUS.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Diomede, hist!

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: A little sound of arms Clanking.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: or am I full of void alarms?

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: DIOMEDE.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: No.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Tis some horse tied to the chariot rail That clanks his chain.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: My heart began to fail A moment, till I heard the horses champ.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: They steal on further, keeping in the shadow.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: ODYSSEUS.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Mind--in that shade--the watchers of the camp.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: DIOMEDE.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: I keep in shadow, but I am staring hard.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: ODYSSEUS.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Thou knowst the watchword, if we stir some guard?

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: DIOMEDE.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: vv.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Phoebus.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Twas the last sign that Dolon gave.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: They creep forward in silence to the entrance of_ HECTORs _tent_.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: ODYSSEUS.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Now, forward!

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: They dash into the tent, swords drawn; then return.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: God!

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: All empty as the grave!

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: DIOMEDE.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Yet Dolon told us Hectors couch was made Just here.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: For none but him I drew this blade.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: ODYSSEUS.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: What means it?

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: To some ambush is he gone?

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: DIOMEDE.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Maybe, to work some craft on us at dawn.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: ODYSSEUS.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: He is hot with courage when he is winning, hot.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: DIOMEDE.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: What must we do, Odysseus?

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: He was not Laid where we thought him, and our hopes are lost.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: ODYSSEUS.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Back to our own ship-rampart at all cost!

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: The God who gave him victory saves him still.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: We cannot force Fortune against her will.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: DIOMEDE.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: vv.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Could we not find Aeneas?

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Or the bed Of Paris the accurst, and have his head?

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: ODYSSEUS.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Go by night searching through these lines of men For chiefs to kill?

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Twere death and death again.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: DIOMEDE.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: But to go empty back--what shame twill be!

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: And not one blow struck home at the enemy!

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: ODYSSEUS.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: How not one blow?

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Did we not baulk and kill Dolon, their spy, and bear his tokens still?

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Dost think the whole camp should be thine to quell?

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: DIOMEDE _takes_ DOLONs _wolf-mask off his belt and hangs it in_ HECTORs _tent, then turns_.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: DIOMEDE.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Good.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Now for home!

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: And may the end be well!

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: As they turn there appears at the back a luminous and gigantic shape, the Goddess_ ATHENA.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: ATHENA.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Little know ye what great stay Of help is found for Troy.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: This very night [vv.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Rhesus is come; who, if he see the light Of morning, not Achilles nor the rack Of Ajax spear hath power to hold him back, Ere wall and gate be shattered and inside Your camp a spear-swept causeway builded wide To where beached galleys flame above the dead.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Him slay, and all is won.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Let Hectors head Sleep where it lies and draw unvexèd breath; Anothers work, not thine, is Hectors death.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: ODYSSEUS.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Most high Athena, well I know the sound Of that immortal voice.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Tis ever found My helper in great perils.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Where doth lie Rhesus, mid all this host of Barbary?

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: ATHENA.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Full near he lies, not mingled with the host Of Troy, but here beyond the lines--a post Of quiet till the dawn, that Hector found.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: And near him, by his Thracian chariot bound, Two snow-white coursers gleam against the wan Moon, like the white wing of a river swan.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Their master slain, take these to thine own hearth, A wondrous spoil; there hides not upon earth A chariot-team of war so swift and fair.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: ODYSSEUS.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Say, Diomede, wilt make the men thy share, Or catch the steeds and leave the fight to me?

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: DIOMEDE.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: vv.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: I take the killing, thou the stablery: It needs keen wit and a neat hand.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: The post A man should take is where he helpeth most.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: ATHENA.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Behold, tis Paris, hasting there toward This tent.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: DIOMEDE.

column11: ATHENA.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: He hath heard some tale of spies.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: DIOMEDE.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Then he shall be the first dead Trojan!

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: ATHENA.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: No; Beyond the ordainèd end thou canst not go.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Fate hath not willed that Paris by thy deed Shall die; it is another who must bleed To-night.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: For me, my guise Shall melt and change in Alexanders eyes, Yea, till he dream tis Cypris, his delight And help in need, that meets him in the night, And soft shall be my words to him I hate.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: vv.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: So speak I; but on whom my spell is set He hears not, sees not, though so near I stand.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: She becomes invisible where she stands.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Enter_ PARIS.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: PARIS.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Ho, Hector!

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Brother!

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: General of the land!

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Sleepest thou still?

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: We need thy waking sight.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Our guards have marked some prowler of the night, We know not if a mere thief or a spy.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: ATHENA _becomes visible again, but seems changed and her voice softer_.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: ATHENA.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Have comfort thou!

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Doth not the Cyprians eye Mark all thy peril and keep watch above Thy battles?

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: How shall I forget the love I owe thee, and thy faithful offices?

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: To crown this day and all its victories, Lo, I have guided here to Troy a strong Helper, the scion of the Muse of song And Strymons flood, the crownèd stream of Thrace.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: PARIS (_standing like one in a dream_).

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Indeed thy love is steadfast, and thy grace Bounteous to Troy and me.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Thou art the joy And jewel of my days, which I to Troy Have brought, and made thee hers.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: O Cyprian, I heard, not clearly,--twas some talk that ran Among the pickets--spies had passed some spot Close by the camp.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: The men who saw them not Talk much, and they who saw, or might have seen, [vv.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Can give no sign nor token.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: It had been My purpose to find Hector where he lay.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: ATHENA.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Fear nothing.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: All is well in Troys array.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Hector is gone to help those Thracians sleep.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: PARIS.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Thy word doth rule me, Goddess.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Yea, so deep My trust is, that all thought of fear is lost In comfort, and I turn me to my post.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: ATHENA.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Go.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: And remember that thy fortunes still Are watched by me, and they who do my will Prosper in all their ways.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Aye, thou shalt prove Ere long, if I can care for those I love.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Exit_ PARIS.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]

column11: Tis not for thee to know.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: CAPTAIN.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Stop!

column11: CAPTAIN.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Come, gather round.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: What was his name or race, What the high God by whom his sires have sworn?

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: What else?

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Whom praise ye there?

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Whose prowess?

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Say!

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Odysseus.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Nay, Praise not the secret stabbing of a thief!

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: CHORUS.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: He came once, of old, Up thro the city throng, Foam on his lips, a-cold, Huddled in rags that hung Covering just the sword Hid in his mantles pleat; His face grimed and scored, A priest of wandering feet, Who begged his bread in the street.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Many and evil things He cast on the brother kings Like one long hurt, who nurseth anger sore; Would that a curse, yea, would The uttermost wrath of God Had held those feet from walking Ilions shore!

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: DIVERS GUARDS (_talking_).

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Odysseus or another, tis the guard Will weep for this.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Aye, Hector will be hard.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: What will he say?

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: He will suspect.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Suspect?

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: What evil?

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: What should make you fear?

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: A passage?

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Yea, for these mens way, Who came by night into the lines unchecked.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: A sound of moaning outside in the darkness, which has been heard during the last few lines, now grows into articulate words.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: VOICE.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Woe, woe!

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: The burden of the wrath of fate!

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: GUARDS.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Ha, listen!

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Wait.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Crouch on the ground; it may be yet Our man is drawing to the net.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: VOICE.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Woe, woe!

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: The burden of the hills of Thrace!

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: LEADER.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: An ally?

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: None of Hellene race.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: VOICE.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Woe, woe!

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Yea, woe to me and woe to thee, My master!

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Once to set thine eye On Ilion the accurst, and die!

column11: LEADER (_calling aloud_).

column11: Ho there!

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: What ally passes?

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: VOICE.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Ho, some one of the Trojan name!

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Where sleeps your king beneath his shield, Hector?

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: What marshal of the field Will hear our tale .

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: the men who came And struck us and were gone; and we, We woke and there was nought to see, But our own misery.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: The army lost and the king slain, Stabbed in the dark!

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Ah, pain!

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: pain!

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: This deep raw wound .

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Oh, let me die By thy side, Master, by thy side!

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: In shame together let us lie Who came to save, and failed and died.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: LEADER.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: This needs no surmise: tis disaster plain That comes.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: He speaketh of some ally slain.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: THRACIAN.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Disaster, yea: and with disaster shame, Which lights Disaster to a twofold flame Of evil.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: For to die in soldiers wise, [vv.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Since die we needs must .

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: though the man who dies Hath pain .

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: to all his house tis praise and pride; But we, like laggards and like fools we died!

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: When Hectors hand had showed us where to rest And told the watchword, down we lay, oppressed With weariness of that long march, and slept Just as we fell.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: No further watch was kept, Our arms not laid beside us; by the horse No yoke nor harness ordered.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Hectors force Had victory, so my master heard, and lay Secure, just waiting for the dawn of day To attack.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: So thought we all, and our lines broke And slept.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: After a little time I woke, Thinking about my horses, that the morn Must see them yoked for war.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: I found the corn And gave them plenteously.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Then in the deep Shadow I saw two men who seemed to creep Close by our line, but swiftly, as I stirred, Crouched and were seeking to make off unheard.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: I shouted then, and bade them keep away: Two thieves, I thought, from the great host that lay Round us.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: They never answered, and, for me, I said no more but turned and presently Was sleeping.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: In my sleep there came a dream.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: I seemed to see the horses--mine own team I had trained long since and drove at Rhesus side-- But wolves were on their backs, wolves, couched astride, Who drove and scourged; I saw the horses rear And stagger with wide nostrils, stiff with fear, And, starting up to drive the beasts away, I woke.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: A terror of great darkness lay [vv.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: About me, but I lifted up my head And listened.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: There was moaning, like the dead That moan at night, and over me there flowed, So soft, so warm--it was my masters blood, Who writhed beside me, dying!

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: With a bound I sprang up, empty-handed, groping round For spear or sword, when, lo, a young strong man Was close to me and slashed, and the sword ran Deep through my flank.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: I felt its passage well, So deep, so wide, so spreading .

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: then I fell.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: And they, they got the bridles in their hand And fled.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Ah!

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Ah!

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: This pain.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: I cannot stand.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: The Guards catch him as he reels, and lay him on the ground.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: I know, I saw, thus much.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: But why or how Those dead men went to death I cannot know, Nor by whose work.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: But this I say; God send Tis not foul wrong wrought on us by a friend.

column11: NOTES

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: The play presupposes a knowledge of the Iliad in some form, if not exactly in the form which it now wears.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: We are not only supposed to know that Hector, son of Priam, leads the Trojans and their allies (Trojans, and Lycians, and Dardans bold: in tragedy they are also called Phrygians) in defence against the Greeks--Argives, Achaeans, Hellênes--under Agamemnon, king of men, and his brother Menelaüs, husband of Helen.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: This sort of supposition is usual in all Greek tragedy.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: It merely means that the poet takes for granted the main outlines of the heroic saga.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: But in this play we are also supposed to take up the story as it stands at the opening of the Doloneia or Tenth Book of the Iliad.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: Indeed one might almost say that the _Rhesus_ is simply the Doloneia turned into drama and set in the Trojan camp.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: The only other play that is taken straight from Homer is the Satyr-play, _Cyclops_, which tells the story of Odyssey IX.

column5: Rhesus [The Rhesus of Euripides]
column11: but it is likely enough that if we possessed more of the earlier epic literature we should find many other plays closely hugging their traditional sources.
